feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 4:04PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
At 404 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8 miles northeast of Whitney, or 8 miles northwest of Hillsboro, moving east at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
This strong thunderstorm will be near... Hillsboro around 415 PM CST. Carl's Corner around 430 PM CST.
Other locations impacted by this storm include Abbott, Osceola, Lovelace, Woodbury, Peoria, Brandon, Mayfield, and Mertens.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 35 between mile markers 357 and 369. Interstate 35W between mile markers 1 and 5. Interstate 35E between mile markers 371 and 377.

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of central Hill County through 445 PM CST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 4:03PM CST by NWS Jackson MS
entry.summary:
At 403 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Macedonia, or 9 miles northeast of Petal, moving east at 50 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
This strong thunderstorm will be near... Ovett around 410 PM CST.

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT NORTHEASTERN FORREST AND SOUTHEASTERN JONES COUNTIES THROUGH 445 PM CST

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued March 8 at 4:01PM CST until March 8 at 5:00PM CST by NWS Jackson MS
entry.summary:
SVRJAN
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Southeastern Marion County in south central Mississippi... Lamar County in southeastern Mississippi...
* Until 500 PM CST.
* At 401 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Sandy Hook, or 11 miles south of Columbia, moving northeast at 45 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* This severe thunderstorm will be near... Pine Burr around 405 PM CST. Baxterville around 410 PM CST. Pine Ridge around 420 PM CST. Hattiesburg and Oak Grove around 425 PM CST. West Hattiesburg around 430 PM CST.

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued March 8 at 12:59PM AKST until March 8 at 7:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...East winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 60 mph.
* WHERE...City and Borough of Juneau.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM AKST this evening.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured objects and may damage property and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest wind gusts will be around downtown Juneau, Douglas, and Juneau Airport.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM AKST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 8 at 12:57PM AKST until March 11 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills. Wind chills as low as 55 below zero.
* WHERE...South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range.
* WHEN...Until 1 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 5 minutes.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued March 8 at 4:46PM EST until March 8 at 8:00PM EST by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Statement, up to one half foot of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to one foot of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. For the Coastal Flood Watch, one to two feet of inundation above ground level possible in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline.
* WHERE...Southern Nassau County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Statement, until 8 PM EST this evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 5 AM to 9 AM EST Saturday. For the Coastal Flood Watch, from Saturday evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...For the high tide cycles Saturday night into Sunday morning, widespread flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline including roads, parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes and businesses with basements near the waterfront. Numerous road closures are likely, and vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding could also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued March 8 at 1:43PM PST until March 9 at 3:00PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor coastal flooding expected. Inundation of 1 to 2 feet above ground level is possible along shorelines and low- lying coastal areas.
* WHERE...North Coast and Central Coast zones.
* WHEN...From 9 AM to 3 PM PST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Minor coastal flooding due to tidal overflow is expected around high tide. This may lead to flooding of parking lots, parks, and roads, with only isolated road closures expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Gusty winds and increasing wave heights causing wave run-up are enhancing the coastal flooding threat.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 8 at 3:41PM CST until March 8 at 7:00PM CST by NWS Mobile AL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Portions of southwest Alabama, including the following counties, Choctaw and Washington and southeast Mississippi, including the following county, Wayne.
* WHEN...Until 700 PM CST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 336 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. Amounts higher than 2 inches may be realized as stronger storms move in, and a Flash Flood Warning may soon become necessary. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Waynesboro, Butler, Clara, Millry, Silas, Gilbertown, Toxey, Isney, Emory, Gretna, Contwell, Aquilla, Evansboro, Bolinger, Denham, Paragon, Souwilpa, Water Valley, Dunbar and Shady Grove. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Choctaw, AL; Washington, AL; Wayne, MS

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM CST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 1:40PM PST until March 14 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Medford OR has issued a Flood Watch for the following rivers in Oregon...
Coquille River at Coquille affecting South Central Oregon Coast zone.
For the Coquille River...including Coquille...flooding is possible.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible due to additional rainfall expected over the weekend, combined with tidal influence.
* WHERE...Coquille River at Coquille.
* WHEN...From Sunday evening to Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 23.0 feet, Some farm buildings may be threatened and roads covered in low areas by rising water. Expect widespread flooding throughout the Coquille River floodplain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:45 PM PST Friday the stage was 14.3 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached early Monday morning. - Flood stage is 21.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 4:33PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Columbia SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in South Carolina...
North Fork Edisto River At Orangeburg affecting Orangeburg County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...North Fork Edisto River at Orangeburg.
* WHEN...From Saturday afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Some minor flooding occurs along the boardwalk at Edisto Gardens. Downstream from the Highway 301 bridge, some roads off Chiquita street near the river begin to flood. At 10.0 feet, Farmland and lowlands along Highway 301 near Orangeburg become flooded at stages above 10 ft.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 PM EST Friday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue rising to a crest of 8.9 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY AFTERNOON UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 8 at 4:33PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Columbia affecting Richland and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Columbia.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Flooding occurs in flood prone areas near and downstream from Columbia. Flooding also occurs on parts of the Cayce and West Columbia river walk. At 13.0 feet, Flooding occurs in flood prone areas near and downstream from Columbia. Flooding also occurs over much of the Cayce and West Columbia river walk. At 14.0 feet, Roads in low lying areas and swampland downstream from Columbia become flooded. Most of the Cayce and West Columbia river walk is flooded. At 16.0 feet, Old State Road, SC 66, below Cayce becomes flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 PM EST Friday the stage was 12.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 19.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 12.6 feet this evening. It will then fall to 12.2 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will rise to 14.5 feet early Monday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Action stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood stage is 19.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 4:33PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Calhoun, Richland and Lexington Counties.
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Calhoun and Richland Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree National Park-Gadsden.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek. At 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the river become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake overlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet the river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Watch issued March 8 at 3:15PM EST until March 10 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT....Minor to moderate coastal flooding possible. Up to one foot of inundation above ground level is possibly in low-lying areas near shorelines.
* WHERE...Coastal Hancock and Coastal Washington Counties.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Inundation could affect locations such as Deer Isle Causeway, Oak Point Causeway on Deer Isle, Machias, Stonington, Winter Harbor, Bangor, Brewer, Milbridge, Swans Island, South Lubec and Eastport. Breaking waves will cause overtopping of exposed coastal roadways. Areas of concern include but are not limited to, Schoodic Point and Seawall Road. Road debris and minor road damage could close some roadways. Significant beach erosion from previous storms will make erosion prone areas more susceptible to increased erosion. Beach erosion is expected at locations such as Roque Bluffs.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 8 at 3:14PM EST until March 11 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy wet snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 7 or more inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...The southern Adirondacks in eastern New York and southern Green Mountains in southern Vermont.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A rain snow mix Saturday afternoon will change to a heavy, wet snow Saturday night and continue into Sunday morning. Snowfall rates could reach 1 inch per hour at times. Lake enhanced and upslope snow is then expected for the rest of Sunday into early Monday before ending. The highest snowfall amounts are expected at elevations above 1500 feet. The combination of heavy wet snow and gusty winds could lead to power outages.

entry.summary:

The National Weather Service in Jackson has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Scott County in central Mississippi... Northeastern Simpson County in central Mississippi... Smith County in central Mississippi... Jasper County in east central Mississippi... Newton County in east central Mississippi...
* Until 430 PM CST.
* At 212 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 3:02PM EST until March 9 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia, including the following areas, Franklin, Habersham, Hart, Rabun and Stephens, western North Carolina, including the following areas, Eastern Polk, Henderson, Macon, Polk Mountains, Southern Jackson and Transylvania, and upstate South Carolina, including the following areas, Anderson, Central Greenville, Greater Oconee, Greater Pickens, Greenville Mountains, Northern Spartanburg, Oconee Mountains, Pickens Mountains, Southern Greenville and Southern Spartanburg.
* WHEN...From 7 PM EST this evening through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A warm front and wedge of high pressure will interact to produce heavy rainfall at times tonight and Saturday. Totals of 1 to 2 inches are possible in urban areas of western Upstate South Carolina and southern mountains of North Carolina, with totals of 2 to 3 inches possible along south- facing mountain ridges. Soils remain very wet following multiple rain events in the past week, and cannot absorb much additional rainfall. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 8 at 11:59AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A series of storm systems will spread moderate to heavy rainfall across Western Washington this weekend and into early next week. Storm total rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches are possible across the Olympic Peninsula. Snow levels near 2500-3000 ft may limit runoff amounts. This amount of prolonged rainfall has the potential to push the Skokomish River into flood stage.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 2:41PM EST until March 10 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
A complex storm system will bring heavy precipitation to the region Sunday. Snow will transition to heavy rain on Sunday morning. Heavy rain falling on already saturated ground will result in localized urban, small stream, and flash flooding. The highest confidence for flooding is along the coast, while the timing on the snow to rain transition will determine the extent of the flood risk northward.
* WHAT...Urban, small stream, and flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Maine, including the following areas, Androscoggin, Central Interior Cumberland, Coastal Cumberland, Coastal Waldo, Coastal York, Interior Cumberland Highlands, Interior Waldo, Interior York, Kennebec, Knox, Lincoln, Sagadahoc and Southern Somerset and New Hampshire, including the following areas, Belknap, Coastal Rockingham, Eastern Hillsborough, Interior Rockingham, Merrimack, Southern Carroll and Strafford.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain will fall on saturated and partially frozen ground conditions causing rapid runoff. This runoff will cause already swollen small streams to flood.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 8 at 2:28PM EST until March 11 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy wet snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 12 inches, with localized higher amounts possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph, especially the Western Slopes of the Green Mountains.
* WHERE...Portions of northern New York and central, northern, and eastern Vermont, including the Northeast Kingdom.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Isolated to scattered power outages are possible, especially Saturday night into Sunday. Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A mix of snow and rain develops late Saturday afternoon and changes to mostly a heavy wet snow above 1000 feet on Saturday night into Sunday morning, before a brief break on Sunday. Snow will redevelop late Sunday and become heavy at times, especially the central and northern Green Mountains, including the Western Slopes Sunday night into Monday, before tapering off late Monday.

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Ocean, Somerset, Southeastern Burlington and Western Monmouth and southeast Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Delaware, Eastern Montgomery, Lower Bucks and Philadelphia.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two and a half to three feet above normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 3:53 PM and 3:46 AM.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 9 at 2:53AM ChST until March 13 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to 13 ft. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk around Sunday through Tuesday and will be along shores exposed to the northeast and east swell across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher there. Moderate coastal inundation is possible if surf is higher than currently forecasted. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 8 at 5:34AM AKST until March 9 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES HIGHWAY AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS...
.Heavy snow is falling in the Haines and Haines Highway area. Warm moisture will overrun cooler air at the surface, producing heavy snow and raising snow levels over time. As the warm air moves over Haines, snow will become increasingly wet and heavy, limiting snow totals. For areas 600 feet and above, such as Haines Customs, precipitation is expected to stay as snow and accumulate up to 12 inches.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...Haines Highway above 600 ft.
* WHEN...Until midnight AKST Friday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult and is discouraged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest snowfall rates around Haines Customs is expected to be Friday morning with rates around 0.5 to 0.75 inches per hour.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 3:08AM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
A disturbance will work together with a backdoor cold front to produce snow showers midday through late tonight along the Continental Divide and spine of the central mountain chain, including the Central Highlands. Snow amounts up to a couple inches may impact the following major travel corridors: US 550 near Cuba, I-25 between Santa Fe and Las Vegas, I-40 from Tijeras Pass through Clines Corners, US 285 near Clines Corners and I-40 near Grants. Short lived difficult driving conditions are likely, but significant improvement is forecast by Saturday morning. More significant snow accumulation is likely above 8,000 ft in the mountains.
For the latest road conditions, dial 511 or 1.800.432.4269, or visit nmroads.com.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Central Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Sandia/Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Central Highlands; South Central Mountains

cap:parameter.value: ACCUMULATING SNOW TO IMPACT TRAVEL LATE THIS MORNING THROUGH TONIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:36PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A developing moisture band over the North Pacific will stream northeast and into the panhandle starting mid next week. Rainfall total are looking moderate to heavy with 24 hour totals in the 1 to 2 inch range. The main item to watch is a nose of warmer air will move into the panhandle that will push freezing levels over 5000 feet across the southern panhandle and 1000 to 2000 over the north central panhandle.
The item to keep an eye on is additional snow melt from warming along with the rainfall of the heavier rainfall that stream flow will have higher water levels. We will continue to maintain a watch over this potential hazardous situation.
